awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: Experiments on a High Intensity, Coherent Plasma Laser through Stimulated Raman Backscattering
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description

A laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation) is essentially an amplifier, whose operation depends on pumping energy into the electrons of atoms in a gas, liquid, or solid substance called the lasing medium.  The production of very high-power (on the order of a few billion watts), ultra-short (a few billionth of a second) laser pulses places stringent demands on the lasing medium.  Scientists have used elegant optical techniques and plasmas (ionized gas) that can operate at extreme intensities to develop high-power pulsed lasers.  However, further advancement requires understanding processes within the amplifying medium and overcoming technological challenges that limit the output power. This project focuses on achieving increased output power of plasma based ultrafast lasers by combining the expertise and instrumentation available at Delaware State University with those of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL).  The fellowship grant from the National Science Foundation (NSF) Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) provides the Principal Investigator (PI) and her students the support needed to pursue an integrated effort involving experiments, theory, and simulations.  The project offers a unique opportunity for an early career researcher and students from Delaware State University, a member of the Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU), to train at a premier national facility in building a table-top high-power plasma laser. 

Technical Description

The goal of this EPSCoR Research Fellowship is to achieve ultrashort (20-30 femtosecond) pulses at petawatt/exawatt/zettawatt peak power in a table-top plasma-based laser. The experiments will use Stimulated Raman Backscattering (SRBS), in which amplification of a seed laser pulse power occurs via excited plasma Langmuir waves in a configuration of counter-propagating pump and seed beams.  The seed laser will be shipped from Delaware State University and the experiments will be performed at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL) using a pump laser available at LLNL's Jupiter Laser Facility (JLF).  The project involves the installation of the seed laser, development of a plasma waveguide and studies of its characteristics, implementation of a single stage SRBS experiment pumped by a JLF laser, and finally a two stage (two gas jets) experiment. These experiments will explore the saturation mechanism predicted by the particle in cells (PIC) simulations by the PI's group and use an integrated effort that combines theoretical analysis, simulations, and experimental investigation to address the peak power saturation in plasma-based high-power lasers.  The project provides a unique opportunity for the PI and her students to combine home institution's instrumentation with those available at large scale national facilities to conduct experiments that are guided by theory and simulation, and in turn provide useful feedback to validate and help improve theoretical models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Stimulated Raman Backscattering (SRBS) technique utilizes resonant interaction in plasma to coherently mediate energy transfer from a long pump into much shorter seed, providing simultaneous amplification and compression for the seed. Since plasma is impervious to optical damage and has unique dispersion properties, the amplified laser power can grow to extraordinary levels, making SRBS an attractive alternative to chirped pulse amplification (CPA) for achieving high laser powers and intensities. However, despite progresses over the past decade, the maximum amplified pulse energy was limited to milli-joule level due to early saturation. This project aims to overcome the difficulties encountered in previous efforts where saturation problems limited the maximum output power as the size and scale of the laser system increased. Our goal is to establish through experimental campaigns the first table-top high power laser using plasma as the amplification medium. This laser would produce ~20-30fs pulses with peak powers in the multi-hundred-terawatt range.

With support from this grant, we have successfully set up and run experimental campaigns of SRBS experiments at Jupiter Laser Facilities (JLF) of Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory. We obtained gain factors between 3 -5, with pulse lengths of ~ 30fs. As generating a uniform, low temperature plasma with preferred density and length is crucial in applying plasma to mediate light-light and light-matter interactions, especially for the SRBS process at very high intensities, we chose to continue using the inert gas N2 as our gas jet target instead of shifting to other gases that are easier to ionize. Investigations into the gas ejection, distribution and plasma formation processes were carried out which help to gain deeper understanding of the SRBS process and insights into better controlled plasma conditions to implement schemes that are capable of tolerating more unstable plasma environment.

Five Delaware State University (DSU) students were supported under this grant. Students involved in the project had access to state of art equipment and computation tools and learned to tackle complicated laser-plasma physics problems with integrated experimental and theoretical approaches. Participating in experimental campaigns at LLNL during summertime provided students unique training experience with top-tier laser facilities in the nation and to work with many leading scientists in the field, as well as getting acquainted with their peers from other top schools. We also upgraded the operations of the High-Performance Computing (HPC) cluster we built in our lab. The computing speed and data capacity are improved and allows us to simulate initial verifications and testing with the physical conditions that we used in our experiment. Meanwhile, students trained from the project gained knowledge with the infrastructure of HPC and know how to use them to enhance the capacity and competitiveness of research designs. This program broadens and enhances the research spectrum of physics and engineering portfolios at DSU and will help to build the core infra-structure in research at the interface of ultrafast science and plasma physics.
